sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. Why thou little worthless Contemptible Wretch! Do you entertain Strangers with your aversion for your Country, without being able to give one Reason for it; and can you give but one Reason for liking it, which if it were true, would make all others abhor it. The Women fond of thee! Why the Common Hackneys who live by thee, Contemn thee. But such as he think if he is not affronted, he is belov'd.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: You must know, Sir, (to Freelove) he is Jealous of me, that makes him so peevish, he us'd to be very fond of me. Therefore I'll tell you more of this some other time, and in the mean time study all Opportunities of shewing how much I am, Sir, Your most Obedient humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir. This Spark takes leave, I perceive, always alike, I suppose too of every Body alike, and in the same Stile as he concludes his dull Insipid Billet-doux.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Ay, hang him, hang him, he is always dully Brisk and Impertinent. But here she comes who is all perfection.

Madam, Your Ladyships Slave. Be pleas'd to know these Two Gentlemen; this is Mr. Freelove, and this is Mr. Bellmine. You see, Madam, how Communicative I am to you of every thing that is Good; you shall share all my Goods.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: This is a signal Proof indeed.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: This Gentleman is in Love with my Niece, and this with my Daughter. What say you, Madam, shall we be Married all together? keep time, odd, I believe I cou'd— make it a day of Revelling, and a night of Loving, Feast all day and Kiss all night.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Sir Francis, I have all the Respect and Friendship for you, that a Man of your Excellent Parts can require with Modesty, but I must desire you not to talk so loosly before me. Marriage is a sacred thing, Sir Francis, a very sacred thing; yet it is a thing, Sir Francis, that may be abus'd, and may be perverted to raise indecent and unruly Cogitations.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I told you how reserv'd she was. (To Free. and Bel.)

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: I presume you found Mr. Vainly here. I assure you, Sir Francis, I left the Room because he tacitly imply'd the thing Marriage, tho' on his knees, and with all the Chastity and Modesty imaginable.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There she has given the Reason. (To Freelove)

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Can he mistake this for Virtue? I wou'd as soon take a Bully's Rant for true Courage, or a Cringing Designing Courtiers low bow for true Humility. This Ridiculous Cant, this affected Squeamishness is as nauseous to me, as open Lewdness, and I am sure as certain a sign, and a greater Crime, for she adds Hypocrisy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I am so far of your Opinion, that if you will take him aside, I am resolv'd to make Love to her.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What at first! and to what end?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have just now a Project conceiv'd in my head, but I have not time now to impart it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Son Bellmine, you must try to prevail with my Lady here, and as you succeed with her for me, so you must expect to succeed with me for my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Oh for some Art to Charm him from Marina; or at least delay the Match; for I must dally no longer with my old Gentleman. (Aside)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This is a severe Task, Madam, that Sir Francis has impos'd upon me: To require me to make Love to you, and not for my self.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: He is very sensible, Sir, that his Daughter has Charms to secure you from one much more engaging.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Fathers are as Blind as Lovers. And give me leave to think he is a much more indulgent Father, than passionate Lover, or he wou'd dread your greater Power wou'd make me false both to my Love and Friendship: And shou'd Marina make the same Tryal of my Constancy, she wou'd convince me she exceeds you as much in Vanity, as she is inferiour to you in every Charm.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, if Sir Francis had such a Talent of Elocution, I believe he might have succeeded long since. And for his Daughter, I conjecture I am not much inferiour to her in the superlative Charm, Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That never was a Charm to me; tho' I cou'd wish it were one to you, since I can at least equal Sir Francis's.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Sure, Sir, you can have no other design in this, but to try with what temper I can support such Complements.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: That is not my design, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Is it not indeed, Sir? on your Veracity.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, on my Honour, Madam; nor can you suppose it is. Methinks a Lady of your piercing Wit, shou'd in a Moment read ones thoughts, as in a Moment so much Beauty Conquers.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis as dangerous to believe one of you young Gentlemen, as it is difficult to deny so fine a Person.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Convince me, you think me the latter, by allowing me a Moments Free Conversation.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Alas Sir, even to talk thus is a Liberty I never permitted to any before; and I am sure you cannot in reason ask more.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Lovers are always thought Extravagant in their Demands, by the indifferent. Therefore I fear to ask what I wou'd give the World for, that you wou'd let me see you this Evening in St. Stephen's- Green.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Oh me Sir, what wou'd the World say! or what I value more, what wou'd you think?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The World shall never know it, and for me—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What say you Sir, have you no Estate?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Not an Acre, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Nor Money?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Not a Penny.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p:
A strange dull Fellow this! (Aside) And have you really now the Conscience to make Love to my Niece. Can you imagine that she will throw her self away upon you in the Bloom of her Youth; one of her Wit and Beauty. But perhaps you think she has an Equal Stock of Money, and
so hope to make your Fortune by her: But I can assure you, she is in the same Circumstances as you are, not worth a Penny.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I knew it when first I saw her, yet my Love receiv'd not the least Check by that; I hope she will prove as Generous.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Generous do you call it? Death! you make me mad. What a Pox is there no way to be thought Generous, but by becoming Mad and Begging. And pray Sir, if I may ask you a Civil Question, if she were Generous enough, as you call it, and mad enough, as I call it, to Marry you, how wou'd you Maintain her, Sir?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Oh, trust to our Stars for that.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I hope she will have more Grace. Trust to your Stars for that! I wou'd as soon trust you for ten Thousand Pounds. I have not heard a Fellow talk so Sillily in all my life. (Aside)

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And I assure you Sir, were our Circumstances chang'd, you shou'd command that Summ from me. I have so great an Honour for you, and so high an Opinion of your Worth and Integrity.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Strangely Impertinent! (Aside) I beseech you good Romantick Sir, put not your self to the trouble of making these professions to me, for to be free with you, I no more regard your Complements than I want your assistance. A perfect Fool! Methinks too a very ugly, ungentile Man, as ever I saw! (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I hope, Sir, I shall not find you my Enemy in this matter however.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: No, no Sir, you need no other Enemy than your self, and those Stars you were talking of. Your Servant Sir, I must mind my own Affairs now. What a confounded Friend has Bellmine chosen out? no doubt a Sharper, and lives upon him. But I'll quickly part 'em, when he is Married to my Daughter. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis well my Breach with Aemilia is repaired; by his owning he told me who she was, or he wou'd never do me that Justice now; for I perceive by this Declaration of mine, I have forfeited his good Opinion. He cannot relish even Flattery from the mouth of a Man he thinks is in want. (Aside)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: And she has listned to your Arguments, you say, and seems Compliant?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes Sir, she has promis'd to comply with what I desired. (Enter Servant.)
Madam, here are some Ladies come to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Oh me! I wou'd not for a Kingdom be found alone Entertaining Men. This is a Censorious Town, and I wou'd not give them an Advantage over my Bright Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I believe it may be my Niece and Daughter, I order'd them to attend your Ladyship this Evening. Ay, 'tis so, 'tis so. Observe now, Sir, if she has not too much Wit, to be so Generous as to Marry you for Love only, and to trust to your Stars.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I am sure if she Marrys for any other Reason, it shall not be me.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: I protest Ladies, were it any but you, who surpriz'd me in this indecent Criminal Converse, I shou'd never have the assurance to obtrude my self upon Company again.

sp.speaker: Aemi.
sp.p: I assure your Ladyship, we have not perceived any thing Criminal; and if you please to keep your own Council, we are not at all Curious.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Ay, but Madam, to be entertaining men alone, that's the thing grieves me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: No, 'tis because that you have not a Man alone, that's the thing Grieves you. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: For they are so Censorious here, that really I do not in all the Sphere of my Memory recollect one Woman whose Reputation is not Contaminated.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I am sorry to hear that.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Your Ladyships excepted. Truth on't is, they make themselves obnoxious to such Calumnies by their Imprudent Behaviour. For was not my Lady Courtly seen twice in one week at the Play? and was not my Lady Blameless in a Mask in the Gallery? and was not Mrs. Wellbred heard most Impiously and Obscenely to wish it were the Custom in this Town, for Women to sit in the Pit? and is not Mrs. Winlove seen to walk often in St. Stephen's- Green.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I beseech you, Madam, do not Censure Ladies for this, for I have been Guilty of all these things several times.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: What! and do you own it?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Certainly own it; for if there be a Fault in it, it is only when it is made a secret.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Sir Francis, I protest you must pardon me, if I Conjecture these Ladies have strange Crude Notions of Honour.
Well Ladies, you may do what you please, but I wou'd no more be Guilty of these things, than I wou'd sit at a Play in the second Row, which I think very improper for one of my Quality.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And Beauty, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Oh Sir! why really I think it a Disgrace to both. But I hope you do not approve the Behaviour of some, who are remark'd for daily admitting the visits of Men.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I must Confess, Madam, I seldom refuse their visits whose Conversation I like.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p:
Oh hideous! what can you regard in Mens Conversation, that is Divertive? they are all Insidious, you may believe me. They are always pestring a Woman with
their Love, then they beg Liberty to repeat their Visits, and implore a reciprocal Passion; and not contented with that, they desire to wait on her abroad, nay, to meet 'em abroad alone, and Mask'd, and when they have procur'd our Consent so far, then they imprudently proceed to—

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Madam, do not you proceed farther at this time.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: I was only going to Caution you of the Danger, and warn you to keep them at a distance, a vast distance, for some of 'em are so forward, that if we permit 'em to squeeze our Hand, they will incontinently Write to us, and the first Opportunity that offers, will force a Kiss, and they have no sooner ravish'd that, but—

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Indeed, Madam, we want no Caution to avoid all this, nor shou'd I think any Man Impudent, who attempted all these things, if I granted him any one of them.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis my great Concern for you, that's all; for I wou'd have every ones Reputation as unsully'd as my own.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: What a damn'd Malitious Jade it is? (Apart)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: No Niece, you want no Caution in this matter; but you do in another as Material as your Reputation; your Fortune, I mean. For indeed who can preserve a Reputation without Money, or if one shou'd, who regards it?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: So, now for a Lash at me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Look here, Niece, here is a Gentleman has given himself the trouble to come hither to make Love to you, without having Money enough to pay for a License, or the Wedding Dinner.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Madam, I own.—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, he owns it, what wou'd you have more; a very honest undesigning Gentleman as ever I saw.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
I have no hopes you shou'd ever have a favourable thought for me, if it is to be purchas'd with Wealth. But if the sincerest Passion, the humblest Adoration, a Heart
immov'd by any thing but you, can atone for the want of Wealth—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Satisfy your self, Sir, they will not. Nor your fine Person, nor your Wit, nor your Courage, nor your Stars, nor a thousand things more. To convince you how small I think their Power, I will leave you in my Mistress's Lodgings. Come Girls, come away. Madam, as soon as I have dispos'd of my Daughter, I will beg to be made happy.

sp.speaker: Aem. and Mari.
sp.p: Your Ladyships Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant. Nay, I will wait on you down. Do you think I wou'd be left alone with Men?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: So you have very industriously ruin'd your self with the old Gentleman. But let us be gone before her Ladyship returns.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Yes, he will avoid me as carefully as we wou'd an old cast Mistress.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But where is the necessity of perswading him you have no Estate?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That Aemilia may be the more convinc'd it is so.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Wou'd you have her Love a Man because he is poor?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: No, but I wou'd not have her for bear it for that Reason.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He will make use of all his Power to oppose you.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: The better still; I shall make the stronger tryal of her Love.
When Love's sincere, no Enterprize is hard;
And Wealth and Titles then bear no Regard.

div.head: ACT IV. Scene St. Stephen's-Green.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: SUre I shou'd know that Face. My old Acquaintance Timothy in Being!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: What, my dear Rakehell alive still!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Nor Time nor thy Disguise can hide thee from me.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I think indeed it is five years since we have seen each other; but what Disguife prithee?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why that bloated Belly, and those bladder Cheeks, that Crimson Hue, and those huge Pillars which support thee. Thou wer't as Wan and Thin when last I saw thee, as if you were just escaped from the Gallies.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ease and Plenty have made this Alteration, Eating well, and Lying soft. Thank my Stars, I thrive very well in this Coutry.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then I suppose you Despise it.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: That's but an odd Reason.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: A very common one, for I have observ'd that none Despise Ireland so much as those who thrive best in it. And none are so severe in their Reflections upon it, as those who owe their Birth and Fortune to it; I have known many of 'em, when they come first to London, think there is no way so ready to purchase the Title of a Wit, as to Ridicule their own Country.
But tell me, hast thou thrust thy self into any Business? Hast thou got any Employment?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Yes, a very pleasant one, I am in keeping.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: In keeping!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Ay, I am kept.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Kept!

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Kept! ay kept; so I say, don't you hear.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: But not understand. Kept! for what in the name of Venus? to roll on some Body's Bowling Green?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, Sir, you may be as merry as you please with my Shape, but I have other secret Charms, Sir, I have. For know that I have been in keeping these three years, and by a fine Lady; A Witty Lady.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And a Rich one?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not altogether so Rich, as when I knew her first, but she has somewhat left still.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Then I suppose as her Fortune declines, so does your Passion. And so you are now about quitting her.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: But like a Man of Honour, not till I have first provided for her; I am about Marrying her to a considerable Man.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: O Rare Tim! now her Name?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I know thou art a Trusty Dog, or I had not told you so much; but in a little time you shall know all. And now pray give me an account of your Affairs, for I think you seem to be much in the same Circumstances as formerly.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I do but seem to be so. You must know I'm Marry'd.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: See the difference of our Cases, how I thrive upon one, more than you on the other. But pray let me know farther.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You remember about five years ago, I waited on Collonel Worthy; I attended him to Flanders, where he was kill'd, but before he dy'd, for some secret services, he gave me all his Cloaths and Linning and Fifty Guineas.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Lucky Rogue! sure you fancy'd your self a Collonel then?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
No, I had the humility to dispense with the Title of Captain, which I assum'd immediately after my Arrival
in London; 'tis true I pretended to an Estate too, and so went a Fortune hunting.

sp.speaker: Tim,
sp.p: Very prudently done.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: In short, I met with a Lady who was on the same scent; and we Believ'd, Cheated, and Marry'd each other.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: The common Fate of Fortune-hunters. But what is become of your Spouse?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I can no more give you a particular account of her, than how I spent my fifty Guineas. She first apprehended the Cheat, and taking the opportunity of my being Drunk one Night, march'd off, and I never heard of her since. In a little time after having lost my Wife, pawn'd my Cloaths, and spent all my Money; I return'd to my old way of Living, and have got into a good Service again.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: So 'tis but the Right about as you were.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I wish I cou'd find her out tho, not out of the least Passion for her Person, but for her Fortune, for she has some. Here comes the Getleman I now serve, an Admirable Man.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I saw him to day. But they say he is poor.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You must know that—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Come hither, Good Sir.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: We'll talk another time.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Well, well, Adieu. [Exit Timothy.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: With your Master's Leave, I have an Affair, which I can only trust a Man of your Diligence and Art with.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Your most humble Servant, Sir, I will discharge it accordingly.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You see that Gentleman that comes this way.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Him with the Two Ladies?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The same. That is Sir Francis Feignyouth; go to him directly, he does not know you, and with all the Cunning you have perswade him there is a Lady desperately in Love with him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: With an old Man, Sir!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Have a little patience. First fire him with a description of her, and when you find him eager; seem to have taken him for me all the while, that will vex him. Then advise him to come disguis'd, and pass for me, and assure him she shall meet him here this Evening, and let him know he may be very free with her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It shall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Well, walk on a little, that you may not be seen talking to us. [Exit Trickwell

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And so you design he shall meet my Lady Volant in your place. What will be the effect of that?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He will discover that she had an Appointment with me, and if he is not stark mad, it will Convince him what a Creature she is.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But is this very Honourable in you to deceive a poor Lady thus?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It wou'd be much less Honourable to suffer him to Marry her; for he will not be perswaded but she is very Rich.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: He mistakes her for a Woman of Wit too; But I fancy except Virtue, that is the greatest want she has.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: She has some Wit when she talks to Inferiour People; but when in Conversation with those of Fashion and of Sense, she endeavours to elevate her Thoughts, (as she calls it) and refine her Language, and makes both unintelligible, so is affectedly Ridiculous, To be Witty she spoils her Language, and her Language confounds even what is Wit..

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p:
'Tis strange he shou'd be blind to so many Faults, but you are in the right to prevent his Ruin, since you
hope to Marry his Daughter. Do you start at the Word.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The nearer the Precipice, the more it dazles my sight and understanding. Why you us'd to dislike the thing as much as I, till you saw this Aemilia; and remember if e're I am weary of the Bondage, 'twas by your Example I submitted to it. Tho' I expect to be thought the more prudent Person, who have my fancy for the Lady back'd with a good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You deserv'd to be ill us'd for your suspitions; and may be no greater a Gainer than I am; for (as the World goes) whatever Fortune the Lover gains by his Mistress, 'tis ten to one but the Husband will repay with Interest, to get rid of his Wife. I hope we shall succeed, and shall have no reason to Repent. I am impatient to know my Fate; Let us lose no time; your Emissary's Discourse with Sir Francis may give us an Opportunity to speak to the Ladies; I see them coming, let us walk on. [Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Feignyouth, Aemilia and Marina, follow'd by Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, will you be pleas'd to favour me with a Minuits Audience?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What's thy Business?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I wou'd wish you were alone, Sir. I have something to deliver to you from a fair Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Em— walk on, I'll overtake you, this is my Lawyers Servant about an Extraordinary Affair. And what Commands pray has this same fair Lady for me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Commands! alack, alack, poor Soul she has no Commands, no Sir, her Empire's at an end, and conferr'd on you. Don Cupid has taken stand on your shoulders, and with all his might has shot her thro' and thro'.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Heark ye Friend, if you wou'd have me believe you are in earnest, speak sense, speak sense d'ye see, and don't prate to me of Empires, and Don Cupids, and Darts, and such stuff, but tell me plainly, and in short, what it is you wou'd be at.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Well then, Sir, since you will have it without any Decoration or Preamble, you shall; and truly Sir, I do not wonder you are impatient to know, that the prettiest Woman, the sweetest Woman, the wittiest Woman, and till she saw you, the modestest Woman even in her heart, shou'd slight all the Men in Town, and fall desperately in Love with you, only upon seeing you.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Do not you banter now my Friend? hah! do not you banter.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: To Convince you I do not, Sir, I will tell you where you shall see her, and I will not take one Penny for my pains.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Two of the best Proofs a Man wou'd desire. But to raise my Spirits a little, pray tell me what sort of a Woman is she?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why Sir, in the first place then, she is of a considerable Family.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Phoo, Pox of her Family.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And of a most accomplish'd Education—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: A Pox of her Education too; that may render all her other Beauties useless.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I mean, Sir, she Sings, Dances, Plays on several Instruments, speaks French, and the like, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Ay, now thou say'st something. But her Person, let me hear somewhat of that. She is not little?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Of middle Stature.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: That's well; I hate a Dwarf and a Maypole. A little Frisking, Jumping, tumbling Ball; and a Long, Thin, Scraggy, ungainly Lath. Her Complexion next.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Like her Stature, between Extreams; Neither White nor Brown; Sanguine, but no fix'd Red, except upon her Lips, a faint Blush seems always rising in her Face, but clearest on her Cheoks.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Admirable, admirable! not Lean you say.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: No Grape that's kindly Ripe, can be
So Round, so Plump, so Soft as she.
sp.p: You know the Song.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I am all on Fire. Deiicate Creature! I have done with my Lady Volant, that's certain. I do not want Money, why then shou'd I be a Slave for it? Now her Eyes, her Eyes, if they prove right!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Of a sprightly Blew.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: That's not so well. I cou'd wish 'em Languishing, and of a Glossy Black.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: See them, see them, Sir, and dislike 'em if you can. But her Temper is so Gentle, so Meek—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh I abhor a Termagant; I hate a Mistress that a Man must go to Cuffs with. I wou'd have her just such a Woman as you Describe her, Soft, and Compliant; only her Eyes, I cou'd wish her Eyes were Black.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Ne're mind the Colour, Sir, 'tis not the Colour makes the Eye beautiful, 'tis the shape of it, the Lustre.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Well, well, go on with her Description.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Her Teeth are small, even, white and clean; smooth, and look as if just polish'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: If she answers this Description, I will make thy Fortune, thou hast made me already fancy my self Happy, I am in Raptures. But go on, go on, be never silent in her praise. I am sorry her Eyes a'n't. Black tho'.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p:
'Twere endless, to recount all her Perfections; but to conclude, Sir, to prove how large a share she has of Wit and Judgment, this delicate Creature, with thousand
other Charms, all in their Bloom, offers her Heart to you.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Patience, Patience! I am Five and twenty again, Eighteen, and shall I have the riffling of all these Charms say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For my part, I believe she will deny you nothing No one that Loves so much can. In sleep she dreams of you, and all her waking hours are spent in sighs and wishes for her admir'd Charming Bellmine.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: The Devil! for whom?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For her dear Lovely Bellmine.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: For the Devil.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: What mean you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: For Bellmine! ah Plague is all this meant to him!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Meant to him! why are not you Mr. Bellmine? did she not point you to me this very day as you walk'd here with three or four more?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: No Sir, I am not Mr. Bellmine, nor have I been like him these Twenty years. A Curse on your mistake! that has kindled all this Fuel within me for nothing. I am struck cold already. I fancy my self Fourscore. But Sirrah, I'll be reveng'd on you for giving me these hopes to no purpose. I wou'd not have been balk'd thus for a Thousand Pound.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I am sure Sir, if it be not you, that she Loves, I cou'd wish it were you. I have a greater Inclination for your Service than for his.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What good, will your Inclinations or Wishes do me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, a great deal Sir; since I have committed this mistake, I will persevere in it.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: How, how!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I have already betray'd the poor Lady's Secrets, and to make you amends for this Disturbance, I will order matters so, that you shall be the happy Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I burn again. Let me Embrace thee. But the Way, the Way, the Method, my dear Rogue!

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: You shall meet her, and act like him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: That will be somewhat difficult, I fear me, for an old Man.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: For once, Sir, you may do well enough. I will perswade her to meet you here this Evening as soon as it is growing dark; she shall come in a Mask, and do you come muffl'd in a Cloak; she is so excessively Fond of Mr. Bellmine, that I am sure, she will comply with my Proposal, and with his Desires; therefore you may be very Free with her, hurry her immediately into a Coach; and Fear will make her yield to you, as Love wou'd to him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Excellent, Excellent! I shall not contain my self till the happy hour. But will not you play the Rogue, and deceive me?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Upon my Honour, Sir, it shall be as I say.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Enough. The Honour of a Pimp is sacred. The next thing dear to him is Gold; here are five Guineas for you before hand, that thy Honour may be more sacred; (and pray consider how Guineas are rais'd) and if I find every thing answerable to what you have said, I will Love her, and Reward thee immoderately. I will go and prepare my self, and be sure you be punctual. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.l: How sweet the Profit, how deserv'd the Gain,
Which we as a Reward t'our Wit obtain.
Now to give an account of my Negotiation.

div.stage: Enter Free. and Aemilia; Bellm. and Marina.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: At least Madam, you must acknowledge I am industrious for the good of your Family.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And I suppose, I must be Claim'd as a Reward for your good Service to my Father.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: For my part, I doubt the success of your Design; for I have so good an Opinion of my Uncle, that I do not think he will be perswaded to meet a Mask. I am sure he rails against such People more than any Man.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Railing is no more a sign of Virtue, than of Wit. In this age People are seldom what they seem; there are some go to Church without Devotion. We have Criticks without Wit or Judgment; and some Fight without Courage; and there are Women very precise without Virtue. And I equally suspect the Woman who Boasts her Virtue, and the Man who Boasts his Valour; and it generally has the same effect, we are picked at it, and provok'd to destroy their Reputation.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: To Convince you, Madam, we make a right Judgment of Sir Francis; Come hither Trickwell, and give an Account how you have succeeded.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I have succeeded as much to your Desires, Sir, as for my own Profit. Witness this Gold, Sir. Thus has he Rewarded me for Obeying you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What do you think now, Madam? You behav'd your self very Cunningly to get Money from him. Yet I have often known Men Starve their Family, and Feast their Mistress.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: I remember, Sir, I heard you give a Description of one of your Mistresses, and I entertain'd him with that, which agreed almost perfectly with what he Admires. He is gone in Raptures, to prepare himself for the wish'd for hour.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And you depend on my Lady Volant's coming.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I have Enticed her by the hopes both of Love and Profit; which will make her as punctual to me, as a Sharper wou'd be to a young Rich Cully he had Set. She will no more fail meeting me, than Mrs. Flippant, with her new Equipage, wou'd miss the Strand on a Sunday.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: If she be such a Woman, 'twill be Charity to prevent the Match. But I fancy, Mr. Bellmine, you have some self Interest in this Matter: You expect my Cousin's Fortune shou'd be encreas'd by this, to make you digest Matrimony the better, for I hear you have dreadful apprehensions of it, and are resolv'd to have a great Fortune.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Both Reports of me have been truth, I must confess, Madam; but the more I see this Lady, the more my Aversion for the one, and my Regard for the other, are lessen'd.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: If you Marry for Money, you must expect to be severely Censured by one who has none.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: But Madam, you will not have favourable Thoughts for one who knows that, and yet dies for you. Who wou'd sacrifice his Life to be in that state which he there dreads.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: But have you Consider'd all the Inconveniencies of Marrying a Woman without a Fortune?

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: All, all Madam; and wou'd undergo a thousand more for you.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: And how you will be laugh'd at by the World.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: I'll pitty their Ignorance. I have Consider'd all Madam, all the Hazards, all the Inconveniencies; how difficult to have a Man's Behaviour approv'd by all, that it is impossible to be thought a Kind Husband by the Women, and a prudent one by the Men. But you shall ever Rule your Conduct and my Heart. I give my Heart without Reserve, had I the World, I wou'd bestow it so. I will be still your Slave, still gaze upon those Eyes, and every look shall make me more your Slave. Oh I want words to tell how truly I adore you! or had I words that were Expressive, my Passion is too fierce to utter them.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p:
If you declare your real Thoughts, your Passion cannot be greater than your Generosity; and may be easier Feign'd. You see I listen to your Love, because I believe it disinterested; if I thought it were not, not all your Art
shou'd gain a Moments Audience. I hear you talk of Love, tho' I were silent, to hear, gives hopes.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Let me for ever talk, and only talk of Love. To Love be all the Business of my Life; it were abuse of Life to Live to any other End, be every Moment so employ'd; I talk, but it is Faint and Mean; my Heart now swells, and seems to heave and rage, that I no better can describe its Passion. It bids me say, amongst a thousand things that crowd upon my Tongue, I cannot Love you more, I ne're will Love you less.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It wou'd be a damn'd unconscionable thing now in her, to remember all this after Marriage; for 'tis as unreasonable for Women to expect Love after enjoyment, as for a Man who had spent his Fortune, to expect as much Credit as when he had it in possession. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: What is that you mutter of unconscionable?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why, I say it is an unconscionable thing of you both, to keep us in pain thus, when you may so easily remove it. And to seem to doubt our Passion, when we offer so fair to prove it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: And what is that, Good Sir?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What I cou'd never bear the sound of, till those bewitching Eyes of yours sweeten'd it; Marriage.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Why do you expect that I shou'd disobey my Father?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Why do you suppose that I expect you will be obedient to him?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Nay Cousin, you need not fear he will oppose you; but I owe some Obedience to an Uncle too, and I am very sure, I never shall have his Consent. But we'll talk no farther of this Matter, till we see what becomes of his Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: I think the Hour of the Lovers Meeting is almost come. I suppose you will hover hereabout, to see what will be the Issue of it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It may be some diversion to you Ladies to be Witness to it.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: No, that will not be so proper; we shall be satisfied to receive an account of it from you. Till when your Servant.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Tho' griev'd to part, I ought not to Complain, since you have bid me hope. [Exeunt Free. and Bell.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Prithee Aemilia, why wou'd you put this Constraint upon your Inclinations? I am sure you had rather he had stay'd, I read it in your looks; I found your Eyes had almost betray'd your Heart.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: I found so too. That made me more desirous he shou'd be gone. I have Confest enough for this time.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Yes truly, so you have, since you design to Marry him. For Men's Importunity and our Shyness have the same end.
Their subtle Sex is violent to Gain,
And we Deny, more surely to Obtain.

div.head: ACT V. Scene Continues.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Feignyouth in a Cloak.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: YOnder she comes; now if I can Disguise my self till I get her to a Coach, she's my own. Wou'd it were a little darker however.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Who is there? Mr. Bellmine.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: You see, Dear Sir, what an excessive Sovereignty you have over me, to compel me to meet you. But you have an irresistible way with you; and all the World extols you for a Man of Honour, and I hope you will behave your self like one to me.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Methinks I shou'd know that Voice. (Apart.)
I, I, my Dear, I will; I'll make your Fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Your obedient Servant, Dear Sir; indeed it is as uncommon to meet with a Generous Lover in this profligate Age, as with a Secret or a Constant one. But I Conjecture you to have all these Virtues, or I had not consented to meet you at first Request.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: First Request! What a Pox does she mean? I'm certain I know her voice. (Apart.)

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Pray Heaven, I be not mistaken in my Man. (Aside) But now I have met you, sure you can desire no more.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: By all that's Virtuous, my Lady Volant! Is she the amorous Lady! This was a lucky Discovery; I'll try her farther. (Aside.)
Come my dear, I am impatient till we are more private, I have a Coach waiting at the end of the Green.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: I'll wait on you immediately. Oh Heavens! how near was I to be ruin'd! This is Sir Francis! what can this mean? ha! I have it now. A Trick of that Villain Bellmine's to prevent our Marriage; but I'll be even with him. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Come, are you ready?

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Ungrateful Worthless Fellow! (Unmasking)

Not only base thy self, but wou'd have me too, share thy Guilt: how canst thou be that Mercenary Wretch, to Abuse thy Noble Friend Sir Francis Feignyouth, to deceive his Virtuous Beautiful Daughter, forsake and leave her when the Match is concluded on, and Marry me, because I am Wealthier? But tho' thou woud'st be so Base, think you I am so?
Do you imagine I wou'd be unjust to him, a Man of that Worth, that Honour, so fine a Gentleman, because you proffer'd me a larger Settlement? No, coud'st thou give me this Island, I wou'd refuse it, and rather starve with him.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Now, let me never drink Claret more, if I can tell what it is you mean by all this.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Who do I see? Sir Francis! It seems then you came with a Design to meet some Lewd Woman; oh me unfortunate! is there nothing but Treachery and Inconstancy in the Sex? Have I refus'd so many great Matches, and at last Consented to be yours, and is this my Reward?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Why, as I take it, my Good Lady, you came with a Design to meet some Body too.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: If my Trouble wou'd give me leave to speak! That Traytor Bellmine, whom you intrusted to plead for you, offer'd to forsake your Daughter, and Marry me himself—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: And so you met him to that purpose.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Han't I already told you how I resented his Baseness, when I thought you were he. 'Tis true I consented to meet him, in hopes to perswade him to a more Virtuous and Just Proceeding. I wou'd have conceal'd his Crime from you, being always inclin'd to do Good!

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh the damn'd young Rogue, I'll be so Reveng'd on him—

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: And thus while I endeavour'd to do your Family Service, even at the hazard of my Reputation; you suspect me. This is a plain Conspiracy between you both to ruin me; is this like a Man of Honour? this the Behaviour I hop'd for from the worthy Sir Francis! I am ruin'd, undone, betray'd; what will become of me?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Nay hear me, Good Lady, do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: No, I will never hearken to Man more. I will retire from the World, and leave my Wealth to erect Hospitals to maintain Mad men and Fools; rather than enrich the iniust

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Hear me but speak.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: That Sir Francis Feignyouth shou'd suspect me! the only Person in the World I ever gave the least Encouragement to; I easily cou'd revenge my self, by marrying Bellmine, and deprive you both of my Fortune, and of your Son-in-Law; had I not still a zeal for your interests, and an Abhorrence for his Treachery.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Come, I'll tell you how we shall be both reveng'd on this Insinuating, Wheedling, Deceitful young Dog. I'll Marry you instantly, and will not give him the value of a Rapparce Farthing with my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Why verily Sir Francis, you speak like a Man of Honour; indeed to Marry an injur'd Woman, is the only way to do her Right. But I can hardly Reinstate you in my good Opinion, sufficiently to Consent to that yet.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Nay, I will not delay it a moment; I have a Chaplain ready at my House, and we will spend the Night in Embraces, and Laughing at this Impudent Cozening Knave.— See where he comes, if I were not about taking a surer and sweeter Revenge, I wou'd cut his Throat directly.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: For Virtues sake, let us be gone, I have that Detestation for a Cheat, that I cannot brook his appearance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: We may venture to approach them now; we shall confound her more, tho' I suppose he is already sufficiently convinc'd what a Virtuous Lady she is. (To Free. Entring.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Your Servant, your Servant, Sir, my Honest, Faithful, Plotting, Undermining, Dear, Half witted Rival and Son-in-Law! This was a rare Design of yours, an admirable Design.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: A curious Design, a deep Design! Oh these young Fellows are subtle Dogs at a Plot!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What wou'd you be at, Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What wou'd you be at, Sir, this Lady, Sir. But I shall prevent you, Sir, for I am going to be Marry'd to her instantly, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You are not serious sure? why Sir, I'll convince you that—

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Oh I cannot bear that Traytors sight, let us be gone, I shall faint, if I stay a moment longer. He will have the impudence to deny he made Love to me, and desir'd a Meeting.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I own I did, Sir, but—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh! Did you so? truth will out.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And I design'd—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: To Marry her your self— Not a word more, Sir, nor a step farther— In half an hours time, I'll admit you to wish me Joy. And so your Servant.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Your Servant Good Mr. Little-plot. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What is the meaning of all this? I cannot understand it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: To me the matter is very plain. She has out-witted you; and made him believe you wou'd have Marry'd her; this you see has enrag'd him against you; and being Mad enough to think her Rich, and to be Reveng'd on you, he is gone to Marry her.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: He will be Ruin'd, Undone, Beggard.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: And Marina the less Fortune. That Consideration is of no small moment to you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Your Example is of so much greater weight with me, that it has not only reconcil'd me to Marriage, but I think in my Conscience, I cou'd Marry Marina without a
Fortune. But it mads me that she shou'd have such a Mother in Law.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: She will not be much improv'd by her Example.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As much as a Man may improve himself in Conversation, by Drinking with the silent Club here.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: 'Tis such an improvement as Expert Musitians receive by hearing Bunglers, she may learn what to avoid.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: But is there no way to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: None, that I know of, unless you had some fresh Matter to urge against her. And here comes the likeliest Man to assist you, to furnish you with Scandal.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This will be Joyful News to him. Oh he is so facetious when any one has been Guilty of an indiscretion, and has so many smart Jokes upon the Unfortunate?

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Your Servant Gentlemen. My Spleen has been so tickled just now, at the most diverting sight. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, has any one broke his Neck? or has some young Lady run away with her Brothers Footman? or is the hopeful Son expell'd the Colledge? or has there been a Fire lately in Town? or any Merchants broke?

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Almost as Comical as any of these. I just now met Sir Francis Feignyouth handing my Lady Volant into his House, he told me he was that Moment going to be Marry'd, and bid me come to you to be Confirm'd of the Truth. Ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: And is this so great a Jest?

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p:
Ay, is it not? to have an old Fellow, who is so fond of Whoring and Freedom and Money, make himself a Slave to Marry a Beggar; that she is one I am now convinc'd Come, will you along with me, I have a Cordial for him
that will spoil the effects of Sack-Posset. I suppose the Business is finish'd by this time, he shall not know it before. 'Tis such a Jest!

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No, no, I am Melancholly enough already, and thy Jests always give me the Spleen.

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Well, I'll go alone then, for I long to plague him.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That a Fellows whole Delight shou'd be the Torment of others. Enter Trickwell.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, I have rare News for you. I have found out that will break off Sir Francis's Match.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Be quick in telling it.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hearing you in great concern to day for his Design to Marry my Lady Volant, I went immediately to her pretended Steward, who you must know, Sir, is my old Acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: The properest Person to detect her.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: And wheedled him into a Confession that she has kept him two or three years.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Kept him! To what End?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Why, faith Sir, I believe to much the same End, that you kept the Fine Lady that Lodg'd in Convent-Garden.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This indeed may do, if the Intelligence comes not too late; but can you produce him that we may Confront her with him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: He is waiting for me at the end of the Walk.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hast to him then, and pretend his Lady wants him; send him to us at Sir Francis Feignyouth's, and wait you below till I call.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: It shall be done, Sir.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Excellent Fellow! For thy Reward, if thy hopeful Spouse be in this Country, I'll find her out for you; But away. [Exit Trickwell.
Come Freelove, you will go with me, you may have an opportunity to see your Aemilia.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: That Consideration will carry me any where.

div.head: The Scene Changes to Sir Francis Feignyouth's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Francis Feignyouth and Lady Volant.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: COme, Lady, now you are mine in spite of all my Rivals. I'll have them all to Supper, to Triumph over them. We will have nothing but Revelling, Feasting and Kissing, for our first Month at least. But we'll go to Bed soon, because the Drums and Trumpets will Disturb us early.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: You will find some Duns in the Morning will disturb your Rest much more than they. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What says Your Ladyship?

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Only contemplating on my Good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I'll give you no leisure to contemplate; you shall be busied with Action. I have sent to invite my Rivals from Bellmine down to Vainly; I'd not give a Farthing for a Jewel I must always keep lockt up in my Cabinet. I Love to publish my Happiness. But where are these Girls run?— This Marriage has set them a Madding now to be at it too— Here Niece, Daughter, where are you?
I am sorry, Niece, your Admirer has no Estate, that you might not lye alone to Night.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: If I like his other Qualifications well enough to Marry him, that shall be no Objection.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: She is stark Mad; I must Marry my Daughter as soon as I can, or she may Debauch her to the same Design. (Aside)
But I am resolv'd nothing shall Discompose me to Night. I have sent for some Musick to Entertain you; Desire them to walk in, and show their Art.

sp.speaker: He,
sp.l: YOU Bellamira we Admire,
Which pleases you, tho' ill you use us;
You wou'd taste Joys, which we desire,
And Punish both, when you refuse us.

sp.speaker: She,
sp.l: Those Joys I'd keep as well as taste,
But both by yielding are destroy'd;
For Men are ever in such haste,
E're we have tasted, they are cloy'd.

sp.speaker: He,
sp.l: All Humane Things their Crisis have,
To which arriv'd, they fade away;
So long for Love you make us crave,
E're you Consent, our flames decay.

sp.speaker: She,
sp.l: On what strange Diet Lovers Live;
On hopes the Fair may be enjoy'd;
Love even can Despair survive,
But is by nourishment destroy'd.

sp.speaker: He,
sp.l: Insatiate! I'd my Love repeat,
Only to breathing time agree;
Because I cannot always Eat,
Will you both Starve your self and me.

sp.speaker: She,
sp.l: I grieve Philander to deny,
And yet I loose you if I grant;
Not I alone can Satisfy,
Without Variety you want.

sp.speaker: He,
sp.l: Each Part Variety affords,
Your Hand, your Eyes, your Lips, your Breast;
Believe this Kiss, if not my Words,
For Love by Action's best exprest.

sp.speaker: He,
sp.l: Believe this Kiss, if not my Words,
For Love by Action's best exprest.

sp.speaker: She,
sp.l: That I'll believe, tho' not your Words,
For Love by Action's best exprest.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Why, it is impossible, Mr. Wormwood, that she cou'd be false to me; I will not believe she is Married.

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: No, if thou wert Marry'd to her, you wou'd not believe your self a Cuckold, tho' you saw her a Bed with another Man.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Mr. Vainly, our Quarrels are at an end now.

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Then you are Marry'd. Ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Why, that is kind to rejoyce at your Friends good Fortune.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: But, Madam, is it your way to receive Presents from one Man, and Marry another?

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: How Presents!

sp.speaker: La. Vol.
sp.p: If one shou'd give attention to what every Fop says—

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Nay, Sir Francis, be not angry at that. 'Twere happy for you, if she had receiv'd Presents enough to pay her Debts.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh are you there! That's well. Heark ye Slave have you not often swore to me, that my Lady Volant here was worth—

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Not one shilling, Sir, that I know of.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Andam I Cheated, Chous'd, Fool'd, Abus'd, Ruin'd, Confounded, hah?

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Somewhat like it, truly Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I'll have her burnt for a Witch, and I'll have you flea'd you Dog. I'll do't my self.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay, 'tis plain her tenderness of me, wou'd not let her Ruin me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Hold, hold Sir, you have not yet heard the worst.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Can any thing be worse? what! Can any thing be worse than Poverty?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You shall hear. Come Sirrah, make me a full Confession of all the Familiarities that have pass'd between you two.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Alas Sir, wou'd you have me so ungenerous to Betray a Lady's Secrets?

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Why this is Admirable, this is better sport than I expected.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: No delay, or I'll saw you Windpipe this moment; Be quick, and let me not wast Breath on thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: And before mine is gone.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Why then, Sir, if I must tell— But really 'tis not like a Man of Honour in Me.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Timothy; your Confession comes too late now to save him: 'Twill signify no more than a Pardon after Execution. The more he knows the more he will give to be freed from me, and then I'll leave this hideous Country for ever. (Aside.)

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: What, are you already Marry'd? Have you made such hast to be undone.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Ay, ay, the Knot is ty'd; But come, go on, go on with your Confession.

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: Then Sir, since I may speak, I have for about these three years liv'd with my Honour'd Lady there, as her Steward in Publick, and as her Husband in Private.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh I faint! I dye, I dye! I'm a dead Man, I'm stone dead! (Sits down.)

sp.speaker: Tim.
sp.p: I think I had best sneak off before he comes to himself, least I shou'd be made to verify the Proverb, Confess and be Hang'd. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Good Sir, be pacify'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Be pacify'd! Be damn'd; I'm in a fairer way for that. But I'll do one Meritorious Act first, I'll pluck her Heart out— Let me at her.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: At your Peril touch me; here are Witnesses enough, shou'd you offer me any Violence.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Yes, yes Madam, I am bound in Conscience to be a Witness for you, because you Lov'd me too well to Marry me.

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Fear him not, Madam; we will stand by you: Faith I Love thee better then ever, for the mischief thou hast done.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Dost thou so, Tormentor? I'll have you two swing'd before I dye, that you may be Laugh'd at too. Here, where are my Servants?

sp.speaker: Worm.
sp.p: Come Vainly, we'll spare him the Trouble; let us to the Coffee-House, I burst till I publish this.

sp.speaker: Vain.
sp.p: Ay, pray let us go. Give ye Joy, Sir, Give ye Joy.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What had I to do with a Wife, what had I to do with a Wife! Had I not Ease enough, had I not Freedom enough, had I not Wealth enough! I had every thing but Wit enough.— Oh! I am a Jest to the World, a Scandal to my Name, a Curse to my Family, and a Hell to my self.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: You afflict your self too much.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p:
Impossible! Had she Virtue, that were some atonement for her Poverty. Or had she been a Miss to some
Favorite, and beg'd an Estate of Forfeited Lands, that had been some Comfort. But to be a Strumpet, and a poor Strumpet!—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: 'Tis but giving her separate Maintainance at worst.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: No, no, I am resolv'd on it, I'll separate my self from the World. I am just going, just expiring, Mr. Bellmine, I am wondrous faint on the suddain; all in a cold sweat. But before I dye, let me dispose of my Family; here Mr. Bellmine, take my Daughter, and all I have; you deserve it for the Good you design'd me. But be sure to Plague that Viper with Law, before she gets any thing.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: I despise your Malice, I'll have a share of your Fortune spite of you all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I hope, Madam, you will not oppose Sir Francis's. Design to make me the happiest of Men.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.p: Since my Father has dispos'd of me, I own it is according to my Inclinations.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Sir, Sir, have you no more to do with Timothy, I saw him steal away.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Nothing more. He has Confest all he told you concerning that Lady.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Hah! What do I see?

sp.speaker: La Vol.
sp.p: Trickwell there! Oh I am lost for ever. (seems to faint)

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: A Judgment, a Judgment from Heaven! she dyes and I live. (Starting up.)

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Let her alone, I'll bring her to herself again.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: What, are you another of her Lovers?

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: No, no, Sir, I am none of her Lovers, for I am her Husband.
Omnes, How her Husband!

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Unlucky Wretch! What Devil sent thee here to my Undoing.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: I think thou wert the Spark that banter'd me this Evening so smartly. But no more fooling; I am in no Jesting humour.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Really Sir, I am so well acquainted with her Ladyship, that it is an Honour I shou'd not assume to my self, if it were not Truth.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Fool, Thoughtless Sot! It were for thy Interest, as well as mine, to conceal this now; till I had got a Sum of Money to quit him. For know prating Brute, I have just Marry'd him.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh. Wonderful!

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Oh wonderfull Deliverance! Oh Blessing unthought of▪ I find my strength return; I shall live for ever. I am light as Air. I am in as much danger now of running Mad for Joy, as before for Grief. But take her to thee, go take her, and much good may she do ye.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Oh by no means Ssr, after you is good manners, Sir, she is at your Service with all my heart and soul. Indeed Sir, she is.

sp.speaker: Lady Vol.
sp.p: Be dumb for ever. Or talk his equal now, thou canst do me no farther Mischief, nor can I longer bear thy sight. Farewel, and may each of you find his Wife, what you have taken such pains to prove me. [Exit.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: Truly, I needed not have taken such pains to have known Timothy's secrets.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: We need not wonder at her Rage. But Trickwell, is this the very Lady you Marry'd in London for a Fortune.

sp.speaker: Trick.
sp.p: The very Numerical she, Sir; only she has chang'd her Name.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Thou hast made such a happy Change in my Fortune, that I will make thine; I will reward thee most profusely for this.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Shall I be the only Man, who shall complain of Fortune. (To Aemilia.)
Shall Love so pure as mine meet no Reward?

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Disinterested, Faithful Love, deserves a higher Reward than I can give.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You are Reward above Man's Merit. Heaven can give no greater upon Earth.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: And will you Marry a Woman that has nothing.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Do not torture me with such Questions. I wou'd, I wou'd, 'tis all I ask of Heaven.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Remember I have told you all the Inconveniencies.

sp.speaker: Free)
sp.p: None, none, there can be none. 'Twere Luxury to starve with you. Pleasure and Freedom in a Goal.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Then take this earnest of a Heart, (Giving her Hand) as full of Generosity, as full of Love as yours.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: You give me endless, endless Joys.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: How, how, Niece, will you throw your self away thus? Marry a Man without a Fortune!

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: Even so, Sir. Nor shall I think my self thrown away on him. Remember how lately you had been almost Ruin'd by Marrying for one.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Well, do what you please. I shall never be angry again. A pretty Present this, Sir, she has made you. A fine Woman, and to my knowledge Twenty thousand Pounds ready Money.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.p: Had you the Indies, I cou'd not Love you more, but this is very surprizing.

sp.speaker: Aem.
sp.p: It was an Uncle's Gift I had in England; and I have industriously thus long conceal'd it, that I might not be pester'd by Forutne-hunters, and might be assur'd that he who Marry'd me, had no other Motive but Love. And I am happy that he prov'd so Generous, I Lik'd so well.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Nay then, Madam, I think I may Discover his secret now. Fate design'd you for each other. He too has had the same Design, you are not more alike in Tempers than in Fortune. For I can assure you this Gentleman, who has given
himself the Repute of being worth Nothing, has an Estate in England of Three thousand Pounds a Year.

sp.speaker: Sir Fr.
sp.p: Admirable! Excellent! Nay; I always thought he deserv'd one. A most compleat Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Free.
sp.l: Let Misers be Enslav'd, and Drudge for Gain,
Their Joys are False, tho' they their Wish Obtain.
While no base Int'rest, Gen'rous Souls regard,
And Love and Peaceful Minds be their Reward.
